The initial sweet and acidic compounds were extracted, but continued extraction pulled out bitter compounds from the coffee's structure. This creates a harsh finish that masks the coffee's nuanced flavors.

astringent.diagnosis: Channeling / Uneven Extraction (TDS may be normal but inconsistent)
astringent.description: If coffee dries out your tongue (like an unripe banana), it's usually due to channeling, not just over-extraction. Water is finding fast paths through the coffee bed, creating uneven extraction. Some areas are over-extracted (bitter, astringent) while others are under-extracted (sour, weak). This creates a drying, mouth-puckering sensation that's distinct from general bitterness. The TDS might appear normal, but the extraction is highly inconsistent across the coffee bed.

V60: Improve Distribution Technique - ensure even coffee bed before brewing - execution
Swirl During Bloom - catch high-and-dry grounds, ensure complete saturation - execution
Pour More Steadily - consistent spiral pattern, center to edge, avoid rushing - execution
Check Bed Flatness - ensure even bed at end (indicates even extraction)
Use WDT (Weiss Distribution Technique) - stir grounds before bloom to break clumps - execution
Chemex: Ensure Filter Adherence - proper seal prevents bypass channeling - execution
Improve Bloom Distribution - ensure all grounds are saturated, swirl gently - execution
Pour Spiral More Evenly - consistent circular pattern, avoid rushing - execution
Check for Bypass - water should flow through coffee, not around filter edges
Use Consistent Pour Speed - avoid fast/slow variations - execution

Improve Initial Saturation - pour water in circular motion, not straight down - execution
Control Plunge Speed - steady, controlled pressure (too fast causes channeling) - execution
Press More Evenly - avoid tilting, maintain even pressure - execution

weak.diagnosis: Low Strength (TDS < 1.0%, Extraction Yield may be normal)
weak.description: Not enough coffee material is dissolved in the water. Your TDS (Total Dissolved Solids) is below 1.0%, indicating insufficient concentration. This is different from under-extraction - the extraction percentage might be fine (18-22%), but the coffee-to-water ratio is too low. The cup lacks body and presence, feeling thin and diluted even if the flavors are balanced.

default: Tighten Ratio - use 1:15 instead of 1:17 (more coffee, less water) - macro adjustment
Increase Coffee Dose by 2-4g - macro adjustment
Reduce Water Amount by 30-50ml (keep same dose, less dilution)
Use Bypass Method - brew stronger, then dilute to taste - execution
Grind Finer by 2-4 clicks (only if also experiencing sourness - indicates under-extraction combined with low strength) - micro adjustment

strong.diagnosis: High Strength (TDS > 1.6%, Extraction Yield may be normal)
strong.description: Too much coffee material is dissolved, overpowering the nuance. Your TDS (Total Dissolved Solids) exceeds 1.6%, indicating excessive concentration. This is different from over-extraction - the extraction percentage might be fine (18-22%), but the coffee-to-water ratio is too high. The cup feels heavy, thick, and overwhelming, masking subtle flavors even if extraction is balanced.

default: Widen Ratio - use 1:17 instead of 1:15 (less coffee, more water) - macro adjustment
Decrease Coffee Dose by 2-4g - macro adjustment
Increase Water Amount by 30-50ml (keep same dose, more dilution)
Use Bypass Water - add hot water after brewing to dilute - execution
Grind Coarser by 2-4 clicks (only if also experiencing bitterness - indicates over-extraction combined with high strength) - micro adjustment

hollow.diagnosis: Channeling (Uneven Extraction - TDS normal but inconsistent)
hollow.description: Water flowed through some parts too fast and others too slow, creating uneven extraction. Your overall TDS might be in range (1.15-1.45%), but the extraction is inconsistent across the coffee bed. Some areas are under-extracted (sour, thin) while others are over-extracted (bitter, astringent). This creates a hollow, empty finish where flavors don't connect or develop properly. The coffee bed likely shows signs of channeling - uneven saturation, dry pockets, or an uneven bed at the end.
